commentBody:
Very clever tag team effort here.

Lots of interesting long answers 
with mostly clean short fill.

Mostly. 

Feel free to reply with exceptions
(as a CASE IN POINT).
On 33-Across: Is it just a coincidence that one of the questions in yesterday's daily quiz in Der Spiegel was how many German states have names beginning with B? (answer: five)

"Hey, kitty, what are you going to do today?"
"No idea. Wait. Scratch that."

(That cat had probable claws.)
Spent a long time certain the number of states was "zero" rather than "none." I think of "none" as a quantity, not a number?
Very solid puzzle. Was hung up on GIS for a while. Once I changed it to RAS, the rest of the bottom half fell into place

This was a very fine puzzle, but it was a tough one for me. 
 Much more like a Saturday than a Friday in terms of trickiness.  I spent way too long trying to figure out what PARKAS had to do with "things that might be down for a ski trip," until the lightbulb went off.  That was an excellent clue.

I was also unfamiliar with a lot more things than on a typical Friday for me.  I've never heard of KINPIRA, ESSENE, or Alan PATON, nor had I heard of Hassock or chalcocyanite in the clues.  None of this is a criticism of the puzzle, but it makes me nervous for what Saturday will bring!

Tough one but got through it with some help from Deb‚Äôs column. By the way, the answer for 31A PUNK was inadvertently omitted in the column. Turns out, Deb‚Äôs taking my mind away from indigenous culture to another culture made it more fun!

Also, wasn‚Äôt sure why LUMIERE was not in all caps but I‚Äôd already seen the light to answer it üòÑ. Pardon the PUN! 

For some reason, Napoleon keeps coming up this week. Every day, there has been some reference. I watched a Netflix series where Napoleon III played a key role, and now I see his name (or namesake‚Äôs name) everywhere! The way our brains notice patterns and motifs amazes me.

As far as the Bond song, I couldn‚Äôt NAMEONE so I had to wait for crossings. 

Finished 9 minutes earlier than my average, but I credit the column in helping shave some time off.

Hope you enjoyed Thanksgiving if you observe it!

My reaction to a good dry pun? EAU.

I‚Äôll see myself out.
Since I live in Japan I know the humble home-cooked staple KINPIRA, but I‚Äôm surprised to see that it‚Äôs well-known enough to make it into the puzzle. A gimme that I second-guessed til the end.

Deb I think HAD works for 6D [Bore] more in the sense of she bore/had twins.

Was anyone else mildly surprised to see the word UP repeated in the answers to 6D & 11D? I thought that was frowned upon.

Tough puzzle for a Friday. I had to fight for it!
A tough one with plenty to work on. But give me this over the gimmicky ones or the rebuses anytime. Great workout.
That was super fun. Thanks, constructor!
Can someone smarter than me tell me why ‚ÄúNONE‚Äù is an acceptable substitute for ‚ÄúZERO‚Äù for 33A? Especially when the clue says ‚ÄúNUMBER of‚Ä¶‚Äù?

This took as long as every Friday, very challenging but clearly achievable with persistence. I had TOMB early but couldn‚Äôt get it to work. I‚Äôd eventually the middle top I practically started over, and buried in the middle was the key to the whole thing, somehow revived. Enjoyable struggle. Perfect puzzling.
Thank you for addressing 9D, I filled it in correctly, but it made no sense to me.   Now I understand.

It‚Äôs probably been a minute since the SATs, but analogies like 16-across should go: ‚ÄúSolid : glace :: liquid : ___‚Äù (colons single-double-single, not double-single-double). For next time, and we know there‚Äôll be a next time.

There were so many misdirects that led me down the wrong path again and again.  I put fills in, took them out, put them back (CASEs IN POINT: SNAG, BRITA, ATTUNED), but suddenly everything started to click and most of the puzzle was filled!  Until I got stuck again.  I was startled when it was suddenly done, and sorry.  I was having a really good time.

 Thank you, Willa Angel Chen Miller, maybe you and Mr. Stock could cook up another for us.

The only difficulty I faced today was the inclusion of trivia I did not know. Other than that I found the puzzle easier than this week's Wednesday and only slightly harder than the Tuesday grid from the previous week. Weird. I suppose I was on the constructor's wavelength?

This was hard for me, but didn't take all that long in the end.  The upper left gave me a lot of trouble, and the bottom left wasn't fun either - ark of the starfish, arc, art, oh duh, of course that's ottoman.

If I hadn't finally remembered that Bond movie title I would probably still be staring at the upper left.  (I stopped watching in the Brosnan era, and stopped caring after Moore.)

Cluing was fair overall, and sometimes quite clever, but some of that fill!  At least we know Stock is to blame for that nefarious upper left.  :)

A real Friday workout for me.  I was a little worried.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Lots of good clueing and misdirecting throughout the puzzle - after my first pass I had a few entries with only a few crossing clues giving them support.

SNAP, FLAP, SNAG and SATE began to fill in the middle and before too long the Southern edge filled in, the East and West edges filled in and NUCLEI, NONE and REALTOR got some traction into the NW corner.

But that‚Äôs as far as I got.

Time slipped past as I tried to remember anything after SKYFALL but the empty boxes clung to me like a disease. 

Finally I remembered why I had to finish the puzzle, I had to finish it for Dame Judi Dench and her great modern portrayal of M.

‚ÄúWe are not now that strength which in old days moved earth and heaven, that which we are, we are; One equal temper of heroic hearts, Made weak by time and fate, but strong in will To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield" 

So I gave up and had a look at the blog post, and FALSTAFF became SANTA FE and NO TIME TO DIE arose out of the broccoli floret mist.

Welcome to Scotland.

I may be over-thinking this but is there a correlation between the upper left and the lower right?

scratch that  - case in point
are you awake  - over a barrel   (not very comfortable)
and my favorite -
no time to die   -  nearly ready.

Just a thought.  Happy puzzling.  I hope some of you are smiling.
‚ÄúPhysics research centers‚Äù would have been a much better clue for NUCLEI. Chemistry has almost nothing to do with atomic nuclei.

I really hate US brands/products in crosswords. It makes it very difficult for non-US solvers (KCUP, BRITA).

Also, STEWMEAT?

The rest of the puzzle was fine. But consider this solver's gears grinded.

It's right there in the song, people.

NONE is the loneliest number that you'll ever do
Two can be as bad as none
It's the loneliest number since the number none

I'll get my coat.
This one I I had to work for, harder after a big turkey dinner and too much wine.  Happy Thanksgiving to all my fellow puzzlers!
Today marks my 1000th crossword in a row. I'm not entirely sure there's anything else in my life I have this long of a streak in.
Anybody else tired of fairy-tale clues always referring to the Disney movie?

Why did I decide that Laramie was the capital of Wyoming? Fun fact, it's also at 7200 feet altitude. 

Fortunately TSA at 19A and an erroneous (but not completely wrong) FuLlS (in place of FELTS) at 29A got me back on the right track... the Atchison, Topeka, and SANTAFE.

I enjoyed 35D for the script directive in The Winter‚Äôs Tale,

EXIT, pursued by a bear.

TIL: Essene. A headlong plunge down this rabbit hole brought up the sectarian ¬´¬†Thanksgiving Hymns, which express a powerful anthropology of human depravity redeemed through divine grace¬†¬ª Seems apropos, even after all these years. The text dates from anywhere between the 3rd to the 1st century BCE. Sometimes I remind myself of a retort I received from the distinguised academic who once tried to knock some sense into me. I said: ¬´¬†Why do I have to know this? It‚Äôs a purely intellectual excercise. And she said: ¬´¬†Why? Don‚Äôt you want any?¬†¬ª I‚Äôm always grateful for any and all of the nuggets I mine from the Wordplay column. Congratulations to the constructors on the two beautifully crafted triple stacks. https://www.britannica.com/topic/Dead-Sea-Scrolls
Much like a Thanksgiving meal, this was a lot to digest, somewhat stupefying, but ultimately something to be savored. Post-solve nap is optional.
Great long debut answers and some tricky fill.  A perfect Friday.

The clues for PARKAS and REALTOR worth the price of admission, and also the Ghastly/MACABRE duo was terrific.   
Nicely done, Willa and Matthew.
Eureka! My very first Friday solve!

Re the NONE/ZERO controversy - surely crosswords are an art not a science? The clue points towards meaning, but isn't a synonym. Like the nice crossword clues - PARKAS, SAINTLY, BURN UNIT, TEEUP.
As many are pointing out, quite a lot of trivia today; really made it difficult for me, but that's not a complaint, I just don't happen to know Disney films, arcades, podcasts, Bond films, Japanese food.
Geography is hit or miss, obviously. 
But I too read "Cry the Beloved Country" at school.
However these:
TSA?
RAS?
And FLAP?

Woo-hoo!

Friday frivolity!
Filled by fearlessly flinging my first feels
and following my gut!

Not being flippant!
‚ÄòTwas  a fun little firecracker!

Willa and Matthew must be my faraway friends,
cuz the cruci-vibing was for real!

Fantastic!

Fank you five - nay fifty times!

Are you a wax figure?

[‚ÄúNever mind‚Äù]

&

[Question that can never be answered ‚Äúnone‚Äù]
THIRTYTHREEACROSS

(I was fine with none, and all the rest)

A couple of weeks ago, we had a reference to *A Wrinkle in Time*, which spurred me to reread it.  Lately, I've had more than usual opportunity for reading and Wordplay, and it occured to me that I have never read any other of L'Engle's novels, outside of the "Time Quartet." So I borrowed a Kindle file from the library of an omnibus edition of the "Polly O 'Keefe Quartet"--I made it through *The Arm of the Starfish*--*A Wrinkle in Time*, 'twaren't, and yesterday I got an email reminding that my digital loan is due expire. And, mirabile dictu, this morning * Arm* shows up in the puzzle!

(Bonus points if you can spot the *second* puzzle reference in this post.)

A satisfying, fun, and most lovely pot-pourri today:
‚Ä¢	Tough, satisfying-to-complete areas that required a good number of return-to‚Äôs.
‚Ä¢	‚ÄúWhee!‚Äù splat-fill areas.
‚Ä¢	Exquisite wordplay, as in [Chemistry research centers?] for NUCLEI, [One whose hard work iis showing?] for REALTOR, and [They might be down for a ski trip] for PARKAS.  
‚Ä¢	Spark in the NW and SE stacks, where five of the six answers are NYT debut answers.
‚Ä¢	A riddle!  An actual riddle! ‚Äì [Question that can‚Äôt possibly be answered ‚Äúno‚Äù].

And for me:
‚Ä¢	A simply gorgeous word I don‚Äôt remember ever seeing before: KINPIRA.
‚Ä¢	Answers I loved (SCRATCH THAT, MACABRE, CASE IN POINT, NAME ONE).
‚Ä¢	The rhyming sing-song abutting pair of SALARY ad CALORIE.

Matthew, I always know I‚Äôm in for a first-rate experience when I see your name atop a puzzle, and Angel, congratulations on your debut ‚Äì may it be the first of many!  Thank you both for a splendid outing today!

For way too long had body instead of TOMB -- SCRATCH THAT!  (Got a slight chuckle that it CROSSES NO TIME TO DIE.)

Fun clues, fun Friday.

A crossword-related realization that recently hit me:

I have a superpower!  It‚Äôs my only one, but it is genuine.  And it is this:

When I‚Äôm watching ‚ÄúJeopardy‚Äù, and there‚Äôs a category where all the answers begin with the same letter, I am a beast.  I run the category with no hesitation.  If I am with people and we are calling out answers, I bark those answers out before anyone else, and people look at me with new respect.

I have realized that crosswords are responsible for this superpower; every puzzle brings so much practice in this skill.

Mind you, it is a skill that‚Äôs useless IRL, that adds nothing to the quality of the world. But I don‚Äôt care.  It is a superpower, and it‚Äôs mine!

(2nd post)
A tip for all you carnivores out there: pre-cut and -packaged STEW MEAT (I have no problem with the entry, btw) is usually of of the cheaper cuts, per pound, at the grocery store; but it's frequently the pieces-parts trimmings from more expensive cuts--filet, sirloin--which would otherwise be tossed. So, often a better deal to buy it than a whole piece and cube it oneself.

This is a good Friday puzzle.  Hit a snag with EXIM, as I have never heard of Essene but the full A-Z in the square with the last E didn‚Äôt work, and obv exim isnt a word - but mars at 47A seemed the obvious answer.  Tars?  Gold star, and came out below avg time when I was worried I would be spending a long time figuring out where I had a typo.  Serial was ten years ago?

Oh, something I know! Got 16A easily enough as EAU. But to be precise, Deb, glace means ice (or ice cream), as clued. Glac√©, with the accent, is most often an adjective meaning icy, but also glaze, like on a cake. Gla√ßon, in case anyone wonders, is an ice cube. Useful in a restaurant.

My French is mediocre, but almost all the French clues are gimmes. Yay.

I started crosswords to get through the nights when my baby was born, and today is her first birthday. I guess she knew I would need extra time on the SW corner, so she was up all night! Thank you to all the constructors, columnists, editors, and commenters for seeing me through the craziest year of my life!
Well, I had "are you alive?" for the longest time.

Nice Friday. Very smooth solve, although I admit to asking the room for the answers to the geography clues.  I loved my trip to Santa Fe, but I didn't recall that it was the NM capital -- it's not the feature of the city that most stands out.

Worthy challenge!  

Note to Constructors:  I will NEVER watch "Beauty and the Beast" and you can't make  me!  I'll never be that bored, that desperate, or that deep into dementia.  (That also goes for most of the modern' cartoon' movies from Disney and some of Pixar.)

Once again I am thankful for having studied all of the history,  culture, and belief systems of Old and New Testament times and writings--not voluntarily, I admit, but the perspective and information have been invaluable for puzzles and have led me to writers like Spong and Crosson...  eternal gratitude, especially in these times.

I must ask our son if he got free room and board when he was an RA; I rather doubt it.  He made extra money by tutoring (available for every math class offered by university math dept.)  The "costs of attendance" go far beyond room and board--tuition and books, getting there and back, lab fees, etc.  

29A is not quite accurate.  FELLing is the treatmet of a fabric's surface (blending, softening, etc.--by brushing, generally) and FELTING (usually achieved by boiling the woven fabric) shrinks the fabric, making the weave tighter and even somewhat waterproof.  There is a segment of quilters who do wool applique--usually with FELTed woolen fabric.  The brilliant colors and texture are quite wonderful.  (No, I haven't fallen down that rabbit hole...already have too many quilts in my head!)
Look at that, Deb chose a Slovenian skier for the first photo of the column! Not a gentleman though - it's Ilka ≈†tuhec, a two-time downhill world champion.

Congratulations on a fantastic debut, Willa Angel Chen Miller! Matthew Stock, your puzzle-making skills continue to impress. 

Stealing from Monty Python here: The Dead Sea Scrolls must be ESSENE to be believed. 

This was my slowest Friday in months, mostly because of the quantity of wine consumed with dinner and the hour at which I started solving. I got so sleepy halfway through that I had to the puzzle down. 

A bit of insomnia a few later gave me the opportunity to bumble my way through the rest of the grid. Most of the answers came quickly, but the NW corner was sticky. I didn‚Äôt remember the Bond title, I had never heard of AYI Kwei Armah and I misread the clue for SANTA FE as asking for the state with a capital at 7,200‚Äô (ironically, our house guests drove up from Santa Fe yesterday (and brought all that wine!)).

I finished with a few typos to find and a bona fide error in the 47 square. MARS and TARS both make sense, though obviously EXIm is not a stage direction.
An easy Friday with no lookups‚ÄîI must be living right, lol. I‚Äôd love to name some favorite clues, but there were so many! At any rate, today I learned KINPIRA. üò∫

I cannot figure out how to rebus in FUHGEDDABOUDIT for 1A.

No? SCRATCH THAT.

Lively puzzle, thanks, Willa and Matthew. A good helping of Friday-level sideways cluing.

Now, off to RECON Japanese KINPIRA.

Sticky but fun. I have one quibble. It is indeed possible to answer "no" to the question, ARE YOU AWAKE, especially when some annoying caffeine-head is trying to rouse you from a delicious late-morning slumber.  A more appropriate clue would have been [Question the can't *truthfully* be answered "No"].

Great puzzle. Took me longer than usual, probably because I didn‚Äôt have much left after cooking and cleaning for 28 people. Best Thanksgiving ever.

Happy Holidays, all.

Phew, that was tough but thoroughly enjoyable. So many misdirects for me I spent most of the time rewriting my first guesses. Thank goodness I‚Äôm on digital, I‚Äôd have had no pencil left. One of my worst wrong entries was kneeler, then cushion for OTTOMAN. My only reference for hassocks is the thing you kneel on in church.
I also kept putting in then deleting PUNK as I couldn‚Äôt think of a coffee pod beginning with K.

Love the clue for NUCLEI, ditto 15A. I have uttered it on many occasions with eyes tight shut, praying for 5 minutes of peace from babies and/or small children. Happy days (now they‚Äôre over).
I thought the answer for A15 was ‚Äúare you alive?‚Äù

OK - have to add HATTIP not hattap - come on, PALS short for pale ales, I thought it was funny. BUT, now I know it's PILS for pilsner. Had to take a Check Puzzle to find that error, so wanted to save another poor soul from having to do the same.

Strands #271
‚ÄúGive me a break‚Äù
üîµüîµüîµüü°
üîµüîµüîµüîµ

No spoilers til after "view all replies".

Leave the emus stranded.
Have the Minnesotans complained about the first clue of the mini yet?
68A clue 'Juuuuuuust about done'  seemed to gratuitously  imply something less obvious than NEARLY READY, when just 'Just about done' would have been a perfectly accurate and adequate clue.

Toughest solve for me in a long while.  I struggled in both the NW and SE corners, and there was much I learned.  For example, TIL that SANTAFE is the highest state capital and that KINPIRA is a saut√©ed and simmered Japanese dish.  I enjoyed the subtle misdirection of HAD for bore, and lots of other devious clues. This was just really satisfying puzzle on several levels.

It was nice to see Alan PATON crop up in grid. Reading Cry The Beloved Country as a young teen was a seminal event in the  development of my awareness of the scope of injustice in the world.
Great puzzle!  Thank you, Willa and Matthew!  Almost no proper nouns.  Many clever clues.  I learned about kinpira.
This one took work but was so fun! Thank you!!
As usual way too many obscure proper nouns.

Okay, okay, so I looked up NO TIME TO DIE.  I hoped it would spring this bear of a puzzle open for me and it did.  But just barely.

I had ARE YOU AWAKE in first, confirmed by AKIN -- but after that the entire top was a mystery.  I didn't know AYI; I think CROSSES is very badly clued (what is "in a way" doing there?) and don't get me started on "bore" = HAD.  Just.  Don't.

What's the vowel?  I have BRITA/KINPIRA, but it could be BRETA/KENPIRA or anything at all.  I forgot to look.  Guess I don't care so much.

FELTS as a verb?

My biggest wrong answer stumbling block was MOT for the bit of wit. I had it in mind (bore it in mind?) and I couldn't shake it.  It took me forever to come up with PUN.

This was Saturday-tough for me and not in such a fun way either.  Only my stubbornness propelled me onward -- and, as it turned out today, upward.

I could be wrong, and I imagine I'll hear about it if I am, but isn't saying that an RA gets free room and board like defining salary as free money(unless you're a vice president)?

I have heard the phrase before, but isn't "free" room and board usually offered in exchange for something of value as opposed to being given for none things in return?


On 33-Across: Is it just a coincidence that one of the questions in yesterday's daily quiz in Dainik Jagran was how many Indian states have names beginning with B? (answer: one)
This was really fun!

Another terrible and witless puzzle littered with random proper nouns and awful riddles. Overly difficult and not in a challenging way.
These puzzles have been getting progressively worse throughout 2024.
15A - People can talk in their sleep or lie by saying No to this. Choose better wording - something indicating that No could be a seemingly contradictory response. 
Cannot possibly?? What a joke.
28A, 34A & 4D - random trivia serving no legitimate purpose and poor placement.
12D is another awful attempt of demonstrating wit. 
"Showing" is the only real indicator here. One could easily fit in at least 50 possible answers with this level of vagueness.
24D's answer is totally forced into the grid. Stew is beyond ridiculous when you consider the across clues at 29 & 34.
Where is Sports Connections today?

I would like to nominate 43D/49A as the Natickiest Natick of all time.  Not just because water filter brands are not what I consider general knowledge, but also because kinpira and konpira are both valid entries with respect to Japan.  Did anybody here know that?  Speaking of Naticks, I just realized I still have an unfilled square at 31A/32D.  It's been a long time since I submitted a comment before finishing a puzzle.  Cheers, everyone.
This morning was filled by doing the Friday puzzle in the easy mode and then trying it in regular mode. I still struggled with some clueing but I think it will help in the long run.

Good one. The Bore/HAD discussion reminds me of a favorite Joni Mitchell song, a deep cut called Chinese Cafe/Unchained Melody. first verse contains this lyric: My child's a stranger I bore her, but I couldn't raise her ========== Her line reading (to me, at least) makes the initial meaning of bore sound like "she's bored with me," making the follow-up a surprise. And it was written before it was widely known that she had given up a child for adoption many years ago. Thanks for getting me to re-listen. https://youtu.be/7G333adJxbM

Tricky one today, especially the right side with longer foreign words I had to solve purely from their cross clues. It suddenly got more doable when I finally realized that there aren't ZERO states beginning with B, there are NONE. A good time overall.

I thoroughly enjoyed this crossword, especially since I live at 7200 feet! A fine collaboration by Willa Angel Chen Miller and Matthew Stock! Thanks you two!
I found the clues to be clever. I like when I encounter a word, such as 9D, where I have to think about its applications. 31A is the kind of clue I find very entertaining.
There were a few things I had no knowledge of, but after circling around a few times, I figured them out. A fun one solved in average time!

Interesting the different responses to the number of proper nouns in the puzzle--either "almost no" or "way too many." I did not know any of them except for the water filter, and that was because for a time it seemed as though everyone except me had one.

Even so, I found the puzzle a very smooth solve and quick for a Friday. Learned several new things.

1D was a surprise. I had always thought Denver was the highest at 5,000 ft and couldn't imagine any US capital being almost half again that high. (Depending on your definition of "almost," but close enough. Still gotta acclimate.)
Many, many answers got on the cross. Whew.  Or, as my son cheerfully reminds me, ‚ÄúCrossword puzzles are easy. You only need to know half the answers.‚Äù

Smilied when I got 19A‚Äî it‚Äôs happened to me too many times!

Arcade pair was clever!

Is it just a coincidence that in yesterday‚Äôs Popular Comments editorial they addressed the issue of how many comments about the same B-level clue it takes to sate the average crossword audience? (the answer was four)
Whew!  What a workout!

I found this a challenging and thoroughly enjoyable solve. The NE and most of the S came together reasonably fast, while the NW and part of the mid region were locked in a deep freeze. Once I tumbled to PARKA and PUNK, the rest of the northern ice cover (consistent with 16A and its clue) gradually melted. For a Friday, there seemed to be relatively few obscure (for me) items (AYI, LUMIERE, KINPIRA, KCUP) but all were finally gettable from the CROSSES.

 In a themeless puzzle it‚Äôs always fun to find correspondences among the entries: here SANTA FE and SAINTLY echoed at a distance across the grid‚Äôs diagonal axis, while the light of LUMIERE matched the heat of CALORIE. Among the several French entries there was also one cleverly fractured word: (5D) TOMB - (16A EAU (de Napol√©on). 

This was, I think, my first exposure to KCUPs.  It occurred to me that if we replaced the initial W of 38A WAXFIGURE with an M, it would make an ideal cross with 32D.

Definitely a workout for me, especially the northwest corner, but I got it without any lookups or helps and had an immediate gold star. That is still not quite my norm for the Friday and Saturday puzzles yet, though I'm getting closer and closer to it being the norm, as it is for the other days of the week now, so huzzah!

I even caught my own mistake of putting in mARS first before TARS. I briefly thought, EXIm... Sure maybe it's a showbiz thing that I don't know about... And then slapped myself on the head and laughed at recalling, "Exit, pursued by a bear."

Anyhow it was a fun one for me. I didn't mind that it took me a little bit longer than average because it was good to have a lazy day after cooking the feast. Sadly, our dishes don't sing and they don't dance but the flatware is always entertaining and there was plenty of telling of jokes and lifting of glasses! üïØÔ∏èüïØÔ∏è

Congratulations on a delightful debut, Willa. And I‚Äôm always pleased to see Matthew‚Äôs name on a puzzle. It was a tough but very fair one to solve, and I got some of the trickier parts by working the crosses, but also had a couple of look-ups. I didn‚Äôt know the Ghanaian author or the anti-apartheid activist, but there‚Äôs always a chance I‚Äôll remember them next time they pop up. Maybe.
Oooohhh this was a GOOOOD one. Very challenging as befits a late week puzzle. Great debut...hope to see more from this constructor.

It took me way too long to come up with SANTAFE.

As a native Coloradoan, I was pretty smug about Denver being the highest state capital.  But then it couldn't be Denver, so I wracked my brain trying to come up with the capital of Montana, which I was sure would be the answer.

It's just not fair.  Colorado has by far the highest mountains in the US, but doesn't have THE highest mountain, nor THE highest state capital.
RE 33a: ‚ÄúNone‚Äù is not a number!
Some beach.  I finally got it, but I‚Äôll sleep tonight!
I knew Alan Paton because there is a Kurt Weill song called Lost in the Stars from the musical of the same name which is based on the Alan Paton novel ‚ÄúCry, the Beloved Country.‚Äù

"[Question that can‚Äôt possibly be answered ‚ÄúNo‚Äù] is ARE YOU AWAKE."

Yes--but I felt determined to make CAN YOU HEAR ME work even though it didn't fit.

Don't work for, or use, Google. It's evil.

@Barry Ancona 

STEW MEAT felt forced, didn't it?

@Andrzej 

One might think so, but there are those in my family who routinely call it that.  It always sounds silly to me.

I strongly disliked some of the other, more out-there fill choices though.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
@Andrzej My grandmother always called it that.  In older cookbooks its a common category for non-tender cuts of meat.

Barry Ancona,

So far (8:45am AST) I‚Äôm surprised none has decided to queue up to tee off about the doubling up at 6 and 11 downs.

Or is it merely the food coma delay‚Ä¶

@JohnWM 

It thought it a feature, not a bug.  I had tee up for the first one for some time....

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Andrzej I'll chime in that STEW MEAT sounds perfectly normal to me. Here's a local supermarket website with a search for it and the results: https://tinyurl.com/2db65mha And here's another: https://tinyurl.com/kxw998xw It's definitely a thing.

@Mike

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@B 

I always look up trivia, duh. Today I knew the song title, the number of B states, and maybe some other stuff, but the arcane Japanese dish, the human rights activist and something else I looked up. I enjoy the puzzle element of crosswords, and trivia is not puzzling, is it? You either know it or you don't, and given the US-ness of these grids, and my completely different life experience to any of the intended audience, I usually know almost none of it. Can you imagine solving a Polish crossword without looking up the trivia, even if your Polish were perfect? Human rights activist Jacek? Polish Xmas Eve dish?
@Andrzej You are a brave soul indeed and fully entitled to your "look ups". Even if I were to know Polish culture well, please don't ask me to spell Pres. Duda's first name !

Also, my parents have taught me to not try and remember everything that can be easily checked. My mother was, and my father still is, among other things, one of the foremost Polish historians, and they both never insisted I remember many dates from history. They made sure I understood why stuff happened though. Who cares on what day some battle happened? But why did it happen, why was there a war in the first place? What was the economic, social and political context? That's the important stuff. It wouldn't hurt to remember the dates, all the names, etc, but in the end it's better to understand processes rather than not understand them but be able to recite all the names of all the people involved. Could I know more stuff better? Sure, but what I know is enough for me, in my life as it is.

In today's context: I value human dignity and human rights, I abhor violations thereof, and I do everything I can to educate my students about those rights, but I don't know or remember the name of every hero who fought for them.

Andrzej, 

Well said.  

Just for the record,  
Alan PATON was South African, not American.

@Andrzej Tx. But do try to read Alan Paton's "Cry the Beloved Country". Very much a product of its time and therefore paternalistic, but worth a look, if only for the line "I fear that when they have turned to loving, we will have turned to hating". Thinking particularly of the Israelis and Jews world- wide who were standing up for Palestinian rights BEFORE October 7th. Paton's other book is "Too Late the Phalarope", not as good IMO but the title is spot-on.

Andrzej, 

OK, but please note that 
the very first (1A) bit of trivia 
in the very first NYT Crossword 
was the name of a British general.
@Andrzej Polish Xmas Eve dish? At our house, no meat, but a few pierogi and lots of kapusta! Wesolych Swiat!

@Andrzej 

I would never deny you lookups - that you persist in non-native puzzlery on these is what makes many of us fans of your commentary.  I was just surprised you found this one unusually easy while I felt the opposite...
